natural problem:
A drawer in a darkened room contains $100$ red socks, $80$ green socks, $60$ blue socks and $40$ black socks. A youngster selects socks one at a time from the drawer but is unable to see the color of the socks drawn. What is the smallest number of socks that must be selected to guarantee that the selection contains at least $10$ pairs? (A pair of socks is two socks of the same color. No sock may be counted in more than one pair.)
$\textbf{(A)}\ 21\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ 23\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ 24\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ 30\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ 50$
natural solution: Suppose that you wish to draw one pair of socks from the drawer. Then you would pick $5$ socks (one of each kind, plus one). Notice that in the worst possible situation, you will continue to draw the same sock, until you get $10$ pairs.
This is because drawing the same sock results in a pair every $2$ of that sock, whereas drawing another sock creates another pair.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks total_socks :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "total_socks = red_socks + green_socks + blue_socks + black_socks"
shows  "smallest_number_to_guarantee_10_pairs = 23"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A drawer in a darkened room contains $100$ red socks, $80$ green socks, $60$ blue socks and $40$ black socks. A youngster selects socks one at a time from the drawer but is unable to see the color of the socks drawn. What is the smallest number of socks that must be selected to guarantee that the selection contains at least $10$ pairs? (A pair of socks is two socks of the same color. No sock may be counted in more than one pair.)
$\textbf{(A)}\ 21\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ 23\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ 24\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ 30\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ 50$
 The final Answer is 23
 ### Proof
 Suppose that you wish to draw one pair of socks from the drawer. Then you would pick $5$ socks (one of each kind, plus one). Notice that in the worst possible situation, you will continue to draw the same sock, until you get $10$ pairs.
 This is because drawing the same sock results in a pair every $2$ of that sock, whereas drawing another sock creates another pair.
 Thus the answer is $5+2\cdot(10-1) = \boxed{23}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks total_socks :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "total_socks = red_socks + green_socks + blue_socks + black_socks"
shows  "smallest_number_to_guarantee_10_pairs = 23"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 100 red socks, 80 green socks, 60 blue socks, and 40 black socks in a drawer. What is the smallest number of socks you need to pull out to guarantee that you have at least 10 pairs of the same color? The final answer is 23.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks total_socks :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "total_socks = red_socks + green_socks + blue_socks + black_socks"
shows  "10 * 2 + 3 = 23"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks total_socks :: nat

a_2.formal problem:
theorem smallest_number_of_socks_to_guarantee_pairs:
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks total_socks :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "total_socks = red_socks + green_socks + blue_socks + black_socks"
shows  "\<exists>minimum_socks_to_draw. minimum_socks_to_draw = 23 \<and> (\<forall>n \<ge> minimum_socks_to_draw. \<exists>a b c d. a \<le> red_socks \<and> b \<le> green_socks \<and> c \<le> blue_socks \<and> d \<le> black_socks \<and> (a + b + c + d) * 2 \<ge> n)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

A youngster selects socks one at a time from the drawer but is unable to see the color of the socks drawn. What is the smallest number of socks that must be selected to guarantee that the selection contains at least $10$ pairs? (A pair of socks is two socks of the same color. No sock may be counted in more than one pair.)
$\textbf{(A)}\ 21\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ 23\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ 24\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ 30\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ 50$
 The final Answer is 23
 ### Proof
 Suppose that you wish to draw one pair of socks from the drawer. Then you would pick $5$ socks (one of each kind, plus one). Notice that in the worst possible situation, you will continue to draw the same sock, until you get $10$ pairs.
 This is because drawing the same sock results in a pair every $2$ of that sock, whereas drawing another sock creates another pair.
 Thus the answer is $5+2\cdot(10-1) = \boxed{23}$.
 *)

theorem smallest_number_of_socks_to_guarantee_pairs:
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks total_socks :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "total_socks = red_socks + green_socks + blue_socks + black_socks"
shows  "\<exists>minimum_socks_to_draw. minimum_socks_to_draw = 23 \<and> (\<forall>n \<ge> minimum_socks_to_draw. \<exists>a b c d. a \<le> red_socks \<and> b \<le> green_socks \<and> c \<le> blue_socks \<and> d \<le> black_socks \<and> (a + b + c + d) * 2 \<ge> n)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: You have 100 red socks, 80 green socks, 60 blue socks, and 40 black socks in a drawer. What is the smallest number of socks you need to draw from the drawer to guarantee that you will have at least one pair of socks with the same color? The final answer is 23.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (red_socks \<ge> n \<and> green_socks \<ge> n \<and> blue_socks \<ge> n \<and> black_socks \<ge> n)"
shows  "\<exists> n_min. n_min \<ge> 10 \<and> ((red_socks + green_socks + blue_socks + black_socks) - 4 * n_min + 3) \<ge> 23"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A drawer in a darkened room contains $100$ red socks, $80$ green socks, $60$ blue socks and $40$ black socks. A youngster selects socks one at a time from the drawer but is unable to see the color of the socks drawn. What is the smallest number of socks that must be selected to guarantee that the selection contains at least $10$ pairs? (A pair of socks is two socks of the same color. No sock may be counted in more than one pair.)
$\textbf{(A)}\ 21\qquad \textbf{(B)}\ 23\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ 24\qquad \textbf{(D)}\ 30\qquad \textbf{(E)}\ 50$
 The final Answer is 23
 ### Proof
 Suppose that you wish to draw one pair of socks from the drawer. Then you would pick $5$ socks (one of each kind, plus one). Notice that in the worst possible situation, you will continue to draw the same sock, until you get $10$ pairs.
 This is because drawing the same sock results in a pair every $2$ of that sock, whereas drawing another sock creates another pair.
 Thus the answer is $5+2\cdot(10-1) = \boxed{23}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (red_socks \<ge> n \<and> green_socks \<ge> n \<and> blue_socks \<ge> n \<and> black_socks \<ge> n)"
shows  "\<exists> n_min. n_min \<ge> 10 \<and> ((red_socks + green_socks + blue_socks + black_socks) - 4 * n_min + 3) \<ge> 23"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 100 red socks, 80 green socks, 60 blue socks, and 40 black socks. If you can take any number of socks from each color, find the minimum number of socks you can take, at least 10, such that the total number of socks you have is at least 23 more than four times the minimum number of socks taken.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks pairs :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "pairs = 10"
shows  "least_socks = 23"
where "least_socks = (GREATEST n. \<exists> r g b k. (r + g + b + k = n) \<and> (r div 2 + g div 2 + b div 2 + k div 2 \<ge> pairs))"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A drawer in a darkened room contains $100$ red socks, $80$ green socks, $60$ blue socks and $40$ black socks. A youngster selects socks one at a time from the drawer but is unable to see the color of the socks drawn. What is the smallest number of socks that must be selected to guarantee that the selection contains at least $10$ pairs? (A pair of socks is two socks of the same color.  The final Answer is 23
 ### Proof
 Suppose that you wish to draw one pair of socks from the drawer. Then you would pick $5$ socks (one of each kind, plus one). Notice that in the worst possible situation, you will continue to draw the same sock, until you get $10$ pairs.
 This is because drawing the same sock results in a pair every $2$ of that sock, whereas drawing another sock creates another pair.
 Thus the answer is $5+2\cdot(10-1) = \boxed{23}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks pairs :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "pairs = 10"
shows  "least_socks = 23"
where "least_socks = (GREATEST n. \<exists> r g b k. (r + g + b + k = n) \<and> (r div 2 + g div 2 + b div 2 + k div 2 \<ge> pairs))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a drawer, there are 100 red socks, 80 green socks, 60 blue socks, and 40 black socks. What is the minimum number of socks you need to pull out to ensure you have at least 10 matching pairs? The final answer is 23.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes red_socks green_socks blue_socks black_socks drawn_socks pairs :: nat
assumes h0 : "red_socks = 100"
and h1 : "green_socks = 80"
and h2 : "blue_socks = 60"
and h3 : "black_socks = 40"
and h4 : "1 * pairs = 2 * drawn_socks"
shows  "drawn_socks \<ge> 23"
